history.content:
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/42529379/css-background-image-is-rendered-blurred-and-not-entirely

Also, even if that specific post doesn't fully answer your question or solve your issue, Stack Overflow should usually be the first place you look. If you have a problem, chances are someone else has had it too, and it's probably been solved or explained already on Stack Overflow. If not, you can make a post yourself, and the community there will be able to help you out and is designed for that purpose, as opposed to a place like eecs101.

children.subject:
It's probably blurry because the image isn't big enough. https://unsplash.com/ is great for high quality, free photos, so maybe try finding a different background picture! 

A lot of websites simply have solid colors for the background so that the design doesn't get too cluttered. Subtle gradients can be a nice effect sometimes. Personally, I don't use pictures for backgrounds unless it's like a large banner (like the top of an article or something).

The best case scenario is if your background image is a .svg file. These are vector images that can scale to any size without looking blurry. If you create something in Adobe Illustrator or Figma, you can export it as such.

history.content:
Hi! Im creating a website (very new to creating websites) and I found an image that I really would like to use as the background; however, after inserting it in as the background using css, it is very blurry. I have searched online a lot and am unable to make it any better. Is there any way that I can still use the image as the background but somehow fix it? Any other suggestions? Thanks

Also, how do people tend to create backgrounds for websites besides gradients?
history.subject: Background for websites
